commentBody: Well! That took a few minutes. A fair Friday, I'd say.
Ugh, derma (not a word, it's dermis) and gene set (not a phrase ever used, it's genomes).
Looked to see if somehow I missed that this was a Robyn Weintraub puzzle.  High, high praise in my book.  DONTPOKETHEBEAR and HEREGOESNOTHING.  TAKETHAT, James McCarron. Well done!
Again, not too bad. Thought I was on the same wavelength as the constructor for this one. A little lost at times, but fun to figure outf

Seemed hard, then easy, then I bogged down at ATTACKAD and ANKLETAT.  

As a former insurance lawyer, I thought minimal coverage provider should be GEICO or AETNA.  Nevertheless a good clue for THONG.

In today's mini, the clue "Unit of distance originally equivalent to 1,000 paces" is answered with MILE. Actually, the mile is more like 2000 paces. The Latin passus (plural passus) is the ancestor of English "pace" but means something different. English "pace" means a stride; Latin "stride" is gradus, and it takes two gradi to make one passus. The pace at quick time is defined by U.S. Army Field Manual 22-5 as 120 30-inch steps (strides) per minute; the gradus was 2.5 Roman feet, roughly the same (30 inches). A thousand 30-inch paces would be 2500 feet or less than half a statute mile (5280 feet).

This was just plain fun. Not hard‚ÄîI hope I DONT POKE THE BEAR by saying so‚Äîbut fun for sure.  Great clues for SEASONTICKETS, ANKLETAT, THONG, RAINS, and ATTACKAD; and fresh long entries in HEREGOESNOTHING, TODAYYEARSOLD and DONTPOKETHEBEAR. And a really pretty grid, if anyone cares about that. If I had a wish it would have been to make the crossers a bit harder to extend the enjoyment‚Äîbut they still weren‚Äôt gimmes or uninteresting. Well done.

"I thought Winnie the Pooh needed a bath."
"No. Don't soak the bear."

("But doesn't he need one a week? That's the bear minimum.")

I also thought 2D was ‚ÄòBRA‚Äô. 

In fact i was so confident it was ‚ÄòBRA‚Äô I tried to force words to work around it until the very end.
I had to transform rAbbI bEn into SAUDI DEB to solve.  Lotta other fun like ANKLETAT!  Thanks!
Very enjoyable puzzle. Nice cluing. Some distractions. Some easy areas. 8 greatly enjoyed it.

As a guy who knows a lot of season ticket holders, I can safely say that a fair few number can and do miss multiple football games, symphonies, lectures and readings, ballets, and operas, per season. It's irrational to think we'd be so rational, as a species. Hardly anyone is truly rational.  We need only to look so far as Deb Fischer, who claims humans have nothing to do with climate change  (and that's just the tip of her particular iceberg of irrationality). Other than that small difference, a fine puzzle. I only paused once, because I had RAIDS as the cause of shows being shut down. Guess I go to shows that might get raided, and proud of it! Is that called LACK of virtue signaling?

Having just had a lovely bowl of pesto and glass of claret, I am in the mood to discourse on the difference between pestare -- to crush -- and schiacciare -- to crush ... Pestare is pounding, multiple, repeated applications of force, such as grinding, mashing, as with a mortar and pestle, to make paste, whereas schiacciare is to crush with continuous force, steady pressure. There is a slight crossover when it comes to mashing, one uses pestare for mashing up herbs, schiacciare for mashing potatoes. It depends what you're mashing, since potatoes can be smooshed, herbs cannot.  Arrivederci!

Jimmy Mack, when are you coming back?

Funky grid.  Fun solve.
A bit easy for a Friday but I did love seeing TODAY YEARS OLD. I was not fond of GENE SET and I kept trying to force GENETIC and GENOMES to fit in there.

I have been a board-certified dermatologist for over 25 years.  Perhaps "DERMA" is common in other countries, but I have never, ever seen or heard the dermis being called, "DERMA."  The word, "DERMA," obviously exists but from poking around the internet, it looks like its heyday was back in the 1800s.  

I think the puzzle would have been better off cluing this answer differently (or scrapping it altogether).

11A - SEASONTICKETS doesn't make any sense whatsoever for the clue. Maybe you wouldn't WANT to miss events for which you've bought season tickets, but that doesn't mean you CAN'T. Also, people sell/flip season tickets all the time, if they can't attend the event.

Wonderful grid spanners today! I tried to fit Speedo before THONG, trIM before SKIM, STop before STEM, and scalp before DERMA ü§£ But I happened to make a PESTO pasta tonight for dinner! And today marks the day I became a mother 31 years ago. Happy birthday to my oldest son ‚ò∫Ô∏è

Quickly wrote in fill after fill that, uh, was  w r o n g.  A light went on each time I figured out the right one, and everything started jumping.  Great fun and a most enjoyable puzzle.

Thank you James (and Rachel!).  I'm looking forward to the one in the Times queue.

That seemed awfully easy for a Friday puzzle, didn't it?  I don't track times but I'd guess lot of personal bests were achieved on this one.  The cluing seemed Tuesdayish level...

I sympathize with the criticism of season tickets but I suppose it meant that one can't miss a game because the tickets are already in hand.  I guess.  (It's not great.)

The other long answers were much better, though simple.

Contrary to other commenters, I had no objection to DERMA, as it seemed a natural alternative form of DERMIS to fit in 5 letters (perhaps it‚Äôs wrong, but I think of DERMA as a pluralisation referring to the various layers of DERMIS collectively). My bugbear (which I shouldn‚Äôt poke, I suppose) is GENE SET. My research intersects heavily with genetics and I have never heard that phrase, so was convinced it had to be GENOMES.
I get the clue for 11A but it doesn't click for me. It's more like "probably won't miss purchase". Nothing is certain.
I've never heard STEM as a synonym for curtail... I could be wrong
ANKLE TAT and ATTACK AD  clever, clever, very clever. Grateful to have a puzzle not asking me for celeb names.

Wow, the top half of the puzzle was incredibly difficult for me, yet I managed to fill it in without outside help - I'm proud of myself üòÉ

I found the bottom half much easier and was done with it fast. The top took twice as long, and I entered most answers in pen.

Overall this was tough but enjoyable for me, pretty much the perfect Friday puzzle.

Very nice Friday morning puzzle 

Spent too long trying to trim rather than SKIM 

Thanks

this puzzle both thrilled and irritated me.
im pretty new here and its unusual for me to feel so passionately ambivalent about elements of the same days fill.  perhaps this is a subtle constructors weekend job?
36D.  Get to.  ATTEND?  really?  i know.  weekend.  flex.  stretch. "ive got to get to the party" = ive got to attend the party.  no.  i can get to the party, decide at the door i dont want to attend, do an about face and go home.  a bridge too far and too mushy a clue.  even for a friday.
35D.  on what planet does being argumentative imply hostility?? is it that hostile witnesses are argumentative?  i thought the lawyers are being argumentative.  most argumentative people i know evince this trait without a shred of hostility.  just who they are and what they do.  and theyre usually annoying.  but hostile?  i may well be argumentative at this very moment.  but hostile?  not a bit.  again.  friday.  loosey goosey.  got it.  but no.  just...no.
now...
26A?  wow.  just wow.  among the best clues of the year, by my reckoning.
5D?  bravo.  took me forever and made me grin when it fell.
my objections are all primarily esthetic and not semantic.
as are my huzzahs.
and vis a vis dermis vs derma:
im an emergency doc and i dont care.  no skin in the game.  just stuff to sew.
exeunt.
Who knew that Wyoming and Montana have the same number of letters as Alberta.

That was fun! It also made me feel old, because I actually know the slang and trivia. Presumably, someone my age is authoring puzzles now! (I tried to Google James but couldn‚Äôt find a bio to confirm). The iCarly reference earlier this week was in that camp too. It‚Äôs amazing how quickly pop culture changes. I‚Äôm 5 hours in to that 1940s puzzle they released, and my next plan is to seek help at a retirement home‚Ä¶.

The slightly uncommon terms - Derma, gene set - didn‚Äôt bother me. Yes it‚Äôs atypical. But isn‚Äôt that true of much crosswordese? We‚Äôre all about the obscure and old fashioned :)

Adding to the chorus: Since this is an English-language puzzle, derma should have been clued as a prefix, suffix, foreign term, or archaic English term, one not used since the 19th c. This wasn‚Äôt tricky; it was just off. 

Having said that, it was a fine puzzle. For me, there were enough gimmes to make me wish the puzzle had taken longer, but I really, really liked the fill. James McCarron, come back anytime. 

Happy Friday, all.

Nominations now open for the Deb Amlen Tricky Clues comment of the year. My entry:
2D. OK, maybe I did at first think that ‚Äúbra‚Äù would be a spiffy answer to [It might be on a rack], what of it? The rack in this puzzle, however, holds a HAT.

Loved TODAYYEARSOLD, even more cause it helped open up the LH.

SOVIET crossing MEER tickles. That one took a while. At one point had GENESIS instead of GENESET. Didn‚Äôt get that corner straightened til peeking HAT and ATTACKAD here. I‚Äôd like to think I‚Äôd have gotten ANKLETAT if it hadn‚Äôt popped up while looking but oh well.

Just embarrassed that I had to look up RAYKROC when ARK was staring me in the face.

All in all, not a great choice to try this one during a bout of insomnia! Fine puzzle though.

I was expecting a challenge after yesterday's easy one, and I was not disappointed.

Slow start, probably got about a third of the way through before my first hit, and overall I handled the bottom two thirds before the top.

My biggest disappointment: that 24A and 24D weren't both TRIM. I know, I know, but it would have been fun.

Thanks!
I was today years old when I learned the name of the founder of McDonald's.
If you haven‚Äôt heard it, or even if you have, Mark Knopfler‚Äôs ‚ÄúBoom Like That‚Äù is worth a listen. Or five. Kroc style. Boom like that. https://youtu.be/0sYK2RwH5E8?si=LdGxZ3Y6mb-zFSG_

Good fun! No new PB but I lowered my average once again. My first pass was a grim state of affairs and I did have to dip into the column for a few pointers but all-in-all I enjoyed this a lot.

I didn‚Äôt spot DONTPOKETHEBEAR for a while and briefly opted for DONTTAKETHEREAR, which, deep down, I knew wasn‚Äôt correct, but it‚Äôs a piece of sage advice that has been ITERATED to me over a lifetime of watching horror and action movies. If a HOSTILE threat has started to SKIM the numbers of your group, the LONERS at the back rarely get to raise the ALARM before they‚Äôre TORE away from the pack‚Ä¶ 

‚Äúin the Friday Puzzle, No-one can hear you SCREAM‚Äù

The two terms that threw me off somewhat were DERMA, a prefix, not a skin layer, and GENESET, an expression I have never heard in decades of teaching biology and genetics.

Otherwise, these are minor nits.  Overall the puzzle was challenging and enjoyable.  I loved the clue for ANKLETAT.
Four great long crossers and nice grid! Very enjoyable.

Puzzle moments today:
‚Ä¢	Appreciating the elegant black square design, including the photo album corners.  
‚Ä¢	Inner-fist-pumping at DON‚ÄôT POKE THE BEAR and TODAY YEARS OLD, as well as [Spot likely to smear].
‚Ä¢	Nodding at the cleverness of [Minimal coverage provider?] for THONG, a clue never used in the Times for *any* skimpy bit of wear.
‚Ä¢	Wanting REMOTES for [Show stoppers, sometimes].
‚Ä¢	Admiring the junk-free answer set in such a low-word-count (68) grid ‚Äì SO hard to do.
‚Ä¢	Noting TORE and TEARED, past tenses for two meanings of TEAR.  
‚Ä¢	Smiling at seeing NOON, clued [High time], at the top of the grid.  
‚Ä¢	Wondering ‚ÄúIf iterate means repeat, then is ‚Äòreiterate‚Äô redundant?‚Äù

James, you gave me far more than a mere fill-in today. Just a splendid outing.  Thank you!

Took a shot with DONT POKE THE BEAR after entering ASPEN, the first ‚Äúgimme‚Äù for me, at 3D and was off to the races. I just seemed to be on the same wavelength with James McCarron. At the end, I finished with a PB.
Really had fun with this one. I feel like most days I‚Äôm today years old. That was my favorite clue with don‚Äôt poke the bear a close second.

I didn't initially think I could do this one. Instead of getting some traction and starting to fill in crosses, I was all over the grid, filling in the few answers that I was relatively sure of. I reconciled myself to many lookups and a long solve time. Eventually I just put it aside for maybe 20 minutes and just went down some unrelated internet rabbit holes, which helped. 

I came back, made a few leaps of faith, and it started to fill in. One of the weirder moments towards the end was looking at what I was expecting to be the text from some industrial workplace placard and having some obscure part of my brain unexpectedly suggest to me that it was really a caution against bear-poking. 

Riiight...

I thought sure, why not, I'll try it...I'll be removing it again in a few seconds, but I'll try it...and less than a minute later I got the music.

One of my faster Friday solves, and I didn't look up a thing.
Had no idea that interate and reiterate mean the same thing.

Raced through the puzzle from the bottom to the middle. The upper half was not so breezy, but it all fell into place by the end. A little easy for a Friday, but some good spanners. TODAY YEARS OLD and ATTACK AD were terrific. Believe it or not, I was not quite, but almost TODAY YEARS OLD before I even heard of or learned the meaning of DON'T POKE THE BEAR. I must have been in hibernation all these years.

Uncharacteristically, I haven't read the comments yet, but I'll bet people were held up by Leyte. It was used repeatedly pre-Shortz, so I guess that's why it came easily to me, since I'm no history buff.
Oh, come on!!! It's TOWEL! Make it fit! üòÇ

Wishfully thinking this morning while viewing the puzzle solved at bedtime. You know what would be cool? Instant replay and see how one solved a puzzle in condensed time.

Make it so! ;-)

There were some tricky answers that had me scratching my head for awhile, but still I managed to finish in 27% less time than average.  Had to rip out a few answers to get NW done: had trim instead of SKIM, scalp instead of DERMA, cap instead of EVE.  Re "can't-miss purchases":  You buy season tickets to insure you don't miss any of the games/events in the series; never would have thought of the other interpretations people came up with.
I loved that I knew TODAYYEARSOLD right away.

Typical tough Friday for me. Just a bunch of working the crosses before answers finally dawned on me. Even on review I can see more than a couple of answers that were NEVER going to dawn on me just from the clues. No big deal. Unusual puzzle find today. A Sunday from April 29, 2007 by Henry Hook with the title: "Circle of Friends." Quite incredible piece of construction. Eight theme answers, all of them proper names, and each of them clued in connection with the following theme answer (and the last one clued in connection with the first). Those clues and answers: 23a: ... "and 25-Across have "canine" surnames :" MARKSPITZ 25a: "... and 41-Across sang with their siblings :" JUNEPOINTER 41a: "... and 52-Across are Mormons :" DONNYOSMOND 52a: "... and 69-Across have affiliations with "Jeopardy!" :" KENJENNINGS 69a: "... and 80-Across have mythological creatures as surnames :" MERVGRIFFIN 80a: "... and 99-Across starred in musicals and share their first names with a classic sitcom couple :" ETHELMERMAN 99a: "... and 101-Across are known for their fancy footwork:" FREDASTAIRE 101a: "... and 23-Across are Olympic gold medalists :" CARLLEWIS Wow. Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=4/29/2007&g=99&d=A ...

TALESE was the first answer I was certain of, and it reminded me of his famous essay (from 1966!) "Frank Sinatra Has a Cold". It's worth the read, if only for the nostalgia, but it's wonderfully written, as well. https://classic.esquire.com/article/19660401106/print
Having GENESET (very awkward answer), ATTACKAD (clever clue) and ANKLETAT all intersect was really tough. I kept wondering how an "ankle top" was an image.

There‚Äôs always someone who says the dictionary is wrong. DERMA as clued is in several dictionaries, defined as meaning the same as ‚Äúdermis.‚Äù A Google Ngram search shows that it has trailed off considerably since 2000, but not that ‚Äúit was last used in the 19th century.‚Äù https://books.google.com/ngrams/graph?content=DERMA&year_start=1800&year_end=2022&corpus=en&smoothing=3 It‚Äôs clearly not the up-to-date term for the layer of skin, but it exists. And if it exists, it‚Äôs fair game for a puzzle, especially a late-week one. Some have said, ‚ÄúWhy didn‚Äôt the editors do their job?‚Äù I‚Äôd say they did, although a ‚Äúdated‚Äù or ‚Äúobsolete‚Äù marker might have helped. But on a Friday puzzle, the goal is not to make the puzzle super easy. And of course, dictionaries have editors. And lexographers. Which literally means ‚Äúword studiers.‚Äù So I‚Äôll take the DERMA, with a corned beef sandwich in the side.
Super fun puzzle. I loved the crossing of SOVIET with DON'T POKE THE BEAR.

The criticism of DERMA seems justified, though IMO it wasn‚Äôt really a problem in light the crosses (MEER was certainly no gimme, but the M was easily inferable given DER_A).

But GENE SET? Come in, folks. This is ‚Äúcomputer storage‚Äù all over again.

The complaints are focusing on the question: What would ‚Äúgene set‚Äù be most likely to denote in an academic paper or textbook?

When the right question is actually: How can ‚ÄúGENE SET‚Äù be interpreted to fit with its usage in today‚Äôs puzzle?

And this isn‚Äôt even a tough one ‚Äî the phrase ‚Äúgene set‚Äù, in addition to any specific technical definitions it may carry, can be viewed as a synonymous formulation of the more generic phrase, ‚Äúa set of genes‚Äù. And that‚Äôs certainly something that clones share.

Side note. Just it kind of interesting that 14 down crosses 23 across. Because...

... if you turn 14 down to the right at the 'M,'  that reads as....

DERMEER

.....
Nice crunchy Friday!  I always grimace a little with this layout, knowing that working down through the SW will peter out and I‚Äôll have to come back to the NE.

I was thinking of Isabel Allende until Gay TALESE tapped me on the shoulder.   That meant ALABAMA wasn't the filming site, but ARMENIA fit, as did ALGERIA and ...finally, lovely ALBERTA.

There are quite a few "sticks" in an orchestra, if you care to be extremely imprecise.  And why GENE SET rather than GENOME?
DERMA, not DERMIS?  I kept trying TRIM here, there, and everywhere, and it never fit....  
The corner with 31/32/33D had me feeling like a PATSY--a SAILOR lost at sea--until ...At last!  An ARK.  

Oh, and SCREAM--far too close to the box cutter clue--and the color CLARET.

A rather toothless puzzle for me -- nothing terribly offensive but nothing really stand-out either. 

I found the cluing intentionally obscure in a way that, once the answer is revealed and I give an "I guess?" response in my head, over and over, it tends to irk me. I call these unsatisfying solves, where the juice ain't worth the squeeze, so to speak. SEASONTICKETS, GENESET, ATTEND, THONG... the list kind of goes on for this puzzle. Doesn't make for the most pleasant solving experience. 

I found the bottom half much more approachable than the top, as others here have said. Agreed that DERMA should have been dermis. 

Nothing felt too unfair though, and I always love a straightforward puzzle with no tricks, so, I can't complain too too much. ;) 

Happy Friday!

On the one hand, we have the complaints about DERMA and  GENE SET (and HOSTILE and SEASON TICKETS).  
(But no one seems to have an issue with Jan van der MEER.  Is that intended to be an alternative name for the famous Delft painter [usually called "Vermeer"], or a reference to the [obscure]  Haarlem landscape painters?)

On the other hand, we have the excellent clueing of "Spot likely to smear", "Image that's just over a foot", and the lovely debut of TODAY YEARS' OLD.
And, as a bonus, we get Deb's hilarious "Rack" comment.

My verdict:  Fine Friday puzzle.
Thanks, James McCarron!

Sometimes, when there's a newly coined phrase I've never¬†heard, I'll guess, based on what I've already filled in. At 51A, I had TODAY YEARS ??? and I confidently wrote in TODAY YEARS AGO.¬† But HOT straightened me out.¬† And TODAY YEARS OLD is much better, don't you agree?

The other long answers were much more familiar.¬† I've often heard DON'T POKE THE BEAR and I've actually said once or twice HERE GOES NOTHING.¬† I'm proud to say I got that answer just off the EREG.

A nice clue for SEASON TICKETS and a world-class clue for ATTACK AD.

Some¬†questions:¬† Are ERASERS purchased separately now?¬† I thought they came with pencils.¬† And if people don't bring pencils (or erasable¬†pens) to school anymore, then what do you need ERASERS for?

And is GENE SET a phrase?¬† Don't you just share genes?¬† Or all your genes?¬† If you're sharing millions (or is it billions?) of genes as clones do, "SET" somehow sounds too limiting.

A clean, enjoyable puzzle with no junk and lively fill.¬† But I didn't find much resistance.  YMMV.
Knd of tough. 1-down gave me trouble, since I wanted it to be "genetics" but that didn't fit. 26-across was interesting.

Once again, I'm grateful for the 'easy mode' clues, as I needed twelve of them.  That, and hunting a typo: I thought "leytr" looked odd.  It looked less odd when I realized I'd hit the "R" instead of the intended "E".

It does what a Friday puzzle is supposed to do.  What 'horrors' await us tomorrow?

Hurray for 51A! That has to be a debut (haven't read through the column yet - but I'm betting so). 

Wonderful Friday challenge. Just mean enough, but no blood shed. Thanks!

Had to laugh hard at @xworddeb 's comment re: 2D, as she thought of a bra being on a rack. At my daughter's wedding, the "best man" who was actually the groom's twin sister, read a magnificent toast that she penned on her way to the wedding. It had everyone rolling. It detailed their lives, how she would get them in trouble, but he always got the punishment. But the best line was undoubtedly: You grew a beard and I grew a rack. 

And this puzzle... I went through it once and thought I'd never finish it. Then, suddenly, words started filling in. Slowly, my brain remembered stuff. Important stuff. Banal stuff. Did pretty well for a Friday! So, keep at it! I was TODAY DAYS OLD when I realized Fridays are getting easier for me! I never thought it could happen!

The hat trick of delightful puzzles this week. Wednesday, Thursday and today. Just enough of a challenge to keep you interested but easy enough to not get frustrated. Been doing crossword puzzles for some 50+ years and have never lost interest. Thanks NYT.
Loved this one. The L in 41 across (LAYS) was my last fill. If this puzzle was done years ago (pre-90s), it wouldn‚Äôt have been a misdirect for me.

I‚Äôm guessing that at the premier indie crossword puzzle sites, THONG is clued more like [Fun-size coverage?].

A nice puzzle, but with many clues that made me wonder CAN IT BE that off the rack?

This puzzle sparkled, not a single clinker in the bin. Nice to see Mo SALAH make an appearance, a debut even? (Even though he does play for Liverpool.) More soccer clues please, fewer baseball players from the '50s. And the Hammers play in CLARET and blue kit.

Wouldn't it be nice if the NYT would publish the words that will get your comment flagged for review?  I submitted a comment several minutes ago that still has not posted and I can't stand not knowing exactly where I went wrong.  The only words I used with negative connotation were "ignorant" and "miserable", but those don't seem flag-worthy.
Tough one for me, but sooo good! Thank you, James! Loved ANKLETAT. I have one. They hurt like the dickens when you get one. Have a wonderful Friday, y‚Äôall.

I made it all the way through the puzzle, with some judicious lookups of some of the facts I confess, only to be done in at the end by the cross of Big name in chips and Big name in fast food. Because I didn't cotton to the wordplay, I rationalized that LAoS must be one of the countries with a big computer chip industry.  (And sorry Ray Kroc, I do know who you are.) Head smack. 
And hey, DEB made the puzzle!

A great Friday puzzle! Thank you, James McCarron! Loved TODAY YEARS OLD. And [Image just over a foot]; ha! Good one. TIL where Kotoka International Airport is, and that Brokeback Mountain was not filmed mostly in MONTANA (though it fit so perfectly!). Had a few wrong things in there (TIE on a rack) but kept circling back around and eventually everything fell into place.  Great clues and great puzzle.

I foolishly tried Albania when I had ALB‚Äî-A for 45 across even though I knew it couldn‚Äôt be.   I love Canadian viewpoint humor:  A Canadian once asked me if I had ever been in the Rockies before, I said, ‚Äúyes, in Montana, Colorado and Wyoming‚Äù.  She laughed and asked, ‚ÄúOh, do the Rockies extend into the States?‚Äù
Fabulous Friday! Grazie James!

Solid Friday, good cluing. No look-ups. Yippeee. 
Waiting on delivery of a new washer and dryer - recovering from the sticker shock. I figure I'd better enjoy them accordingly!
Have a good day, puzzlers!

One more unusual puzzle find. A Thursday from June 21, 2012 by Caleb Emmons. In that one for the theme clues, the beginning square number was actually part of the answer. e.g. 4down HORSEMEN - so... 4 horsemen Some others 18a - HOLEROUND 19d - EIGHTYFOUR 21d - JUMPSTREET 39d - YEARSOLD Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=6/21/2012&g=39&d=D ...

Think I'll go out to ALBERTA,
weather's good there in the fall...

Nice Friday puzzle, but perhaps a bit too gentle for the end of the week. A few too many "easy" clues for a Friday offering.

TODAYYEARSOLD is an expression I've never heard or seen, but it was simple enough to figure out. Didn't know DERMA was equivalent to DERMIS.

Took me just over 20 minutes, which seems a bit quick for a Friday. But I certainly enjoyed solving this one.

Thank you, James McCarron, for your gentle cluing of me at 27D, with non-CLAMicidal wording. 

I am sure there are those who would argue that I'm not silent enough for their liking, though!

20 minutes to fill the grid, 20 minutes to find my mistake. ARc/RAYcROC.

Not sure if this was meant to be an Easter egg or not, but 24 A/D could have both been properly answered as TRIM. Neither of the two answers was actually TRIM though.
Enjoyable puzzle. Just under 27. It took three or four minutes to find my boo-boos. Not unhappy with some of the stuff that others are expressing dissatisfaction with.
This one solved very slowly, until it didn't.  As with most of life, it's all in the focus.  Nicely done and thanks.
This was a good Friday workout for me, a little slower than my average. Very satisfying. I liked [Spot likely to smear] and [Can't-miss purchases?]. Thanks for the fun!
Not sure how to report‚Äîthe link to jump to the theme has been broken for weeks, at least on mobile
The five-lettered famous architect that isn't I M PEI and who has appeared 9 times (all Modern Era) in the NYT crossword, Frank Gehry, has died.

I loved TODAYYEARSOLD being in there‚Äîand knowing it was the seed. That was sweet and I love hearing what people learned so belatedly. I've had some good, embarrassing ones, myself! It was a first-round gimme... that and ASPEN were about the only two of those I didn't have to change. 

Had the hardest time figuring out ANKLET AT. Is this some sort of new social media thing I thought!?  CANITBE!?üòè Happily, Deb set me straight! Big ole duh moment for me. 

In any case, nice puzzle! All of them have been over the last several days, but they've all felt pretty hard to me. I think my brain is in a slump, despite my recent MRI results being so beautiful and the most perfect results ever. I just feel sort of slow. 

Maybe it's the horrific (to me) early extreme darkness, along with the snow and cold. And, you know, combine all that with the, um, state of the world... Yeah, I guess feeling slumpy makes sense. 

Still, I have enjoyed all the puzzles and solved them unaided, even if I found them tougher for me. I only SKIMmed the comments because from my quick review, I realized I'm not in the mood for the "too easy" comments or a lot of nitpicking. That's been the case the last few days too. I truly say this not as a complaint or to be HOSTILE to anyone‚Äîpeople can say and rate as they wish‚Äîbut it's good to know one's own limits and do a little self-care. Cheers, all! üòä
That ‚ÄúSpot likely to smear‚Äù was a gem.
A lot of grief and grousing could have been avoided if 14D had been clued " skinny . . . . . tologist".  Maybe too easy, but better than all this outrage.
Derma is the new üêô üêô üêô üêô
A lot of these clues felt borderline, or worse in terms of relating to the answer. Didn't feel good about many of the reveals.
Loved this one. My last fix was the ANKLE TAT and ATTACK AD crossing. It went a bit faster than many Fridays but I‚Äôm not complaining. I look forward to more of your puzzles James.

OH, and one more puzzle find. Never seen another one like this either. A Thursday from June 30, 2011 by David Poole. Theme clues and answers: *"Got it! You want me to play Dorothy's aunt!" : ISEEBEEM *"Get in line, Ms. Gorme!" : QUEUEEYDIE *"Ms. Myers, shall I pour?" : DEEDEETEA *"Supermodel Macpherson, I presume?" : YOUAREELLE *"Sly insect!" : CAGEYBEE and... Basis of the answer to each starred clue, commonly : ACRONYM Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=6/30/2011&g=56&d=A ...
Thinking it was spelled CROC really threw me off!
STEM, SKIM, and SLIT, right in the center ‚Äî not trim, not snip. Made for a nice, challenging Friday.

I was 52A when I learned of a person named Ray Kroc. I've been doing the crossword for years, and I do not recall ever having seen his name. And I had no idea who he was until I looked him up. I was trying to fill an answer like "INNOUT", to no avail obviously.

Somehow, I managed to cause myself a lot of trouble by filling in "START" instead of "ALARM" for 38A (Word with fire or false). It wasn't until I looked up the footballer's name that I realized where I had gone wrong!
My brain hurts
Always thought it was Ray Croc not Kroc ü§∑üèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

@Barry Ancona

I agree.  Quite a few false starts that took a while to fix.

Many "Jeopardy-type" clues but I can usually handle them.  Crosses helped with several.  Glad that I follow the English Premier League.

James may have failed to heed his caution at 14a.

Mike,
Here's your not a word:
collinsdictionary.com/us/dictionary/english/derma
If you can stuff it, it's a word. (But that's another meaning.) Anyhow, I thought it's an ùôöùô•ùôûdermis.
@Dan Epidermis and dermis are different layers of the skin.

@Mike

As for GENESET it‚Äôs a little green painty but acceptable, and I‚Äôll try to explain why (I‚Äôm not a geneticist so correct me if I‚Äôm wrong).

Clones theoretically share a GENOTYPE, a complete set of genes that have exactly the same information.
Humans share a GENOME, which is the set of all the genes you have (but maybe not the same exact ones).
And strictly speaking, a GENESET would be a group of genes that all are used for the same purpose; so for example you might have a GENESET that are all used to repair your DNA. So any of the three could be considered a ‚Äúset of genes‚Äù and loosely called a GENESET, even though only the last one has that official terminology.
If that‚Äôs too confusing, think of it this way. If you and I collect baseball cards, and both have exactly the same cards, that‚Äôs our GENOTYPE. If you and I only collect American League teams, and someone else collects National League teams, then we have the same GENOME and they don‚Äôt‚Äîit‚Äôs like the set of cards you can pick from. And each team could be considered a group of similar cards‚Äîthat‚Äôs our GENESET.
So it would be like saying you and I both have the same CARDSET if our cards are the same‚Äîtrue enough, but a little imprecise and maybe not the terminology real card collectors would use. But good enough for everyone else, and I certainly wouldn‚Äôt break a great puzzle nitpicking over it.
There‚Äôs my understanding and if someone has a better explanation, or I‚Äôm missing something, please correct me.
@SP and here's a link that explains it https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5858940/

@Leontion

Thanks for the clarification! I knew someone would help me out! Also appreciate the link.

userLocation: Hogtown, a great place for beer

commentBody:
@Leontion
Great link and the other thing this points out that many people don‚Äôt realize is that of your entire genome (all your DNA, as you corrected me about) only 1% is actually used for coding proteins that make up your body, .5% are regulatory sequences (like where to stop and start) and the rest is just junk‚Äîstuff that‚Äôs never used, maybe leftover genetic sequences from when we were prehistoric raccoons that got turned off. Maybe there‚Äôs a code for a tail our ancestors used to have that we don‚Äôt need anymore. Now that I think of it, there was a fun (but otherwise ridiculous) little Star Trek TNG episode about that, where Barkley passed along some virus which activated everyone‚Äôs latent genomic material; Picard became a scared little loris, Troi became an amphibian, Riker became an Neanderthal, etc.

@Barry Ancona
Derma is completely obsolete and not used by anyone anymore.

@Francis
Did you read about what a gene set actually is, and why it‚Äôs inapt for this clue? It doesn‚Äôt mean genome. Sure, you could argue that they actually just mean a set of genes, but that‚Äôs extremely green paint.

@Wggwg

Yeah, but the thing is, this is a crossword puzzle, not a conference of the Genetics Society of America.

Constructors and clue writers come from many walks of life, many as important as yours or mine, though they might be quite different.

It's important to understand that their knowledge is not necessarily going to be as deep as yours is in your specialty, or as mine is in my specialty.

They produced a puzzle as best they could.

At least that's the way I see it.

@Francis
Yeah sure, but then we have the NYT whose job is to edit these crosswords that we‚Äôre paying for. Those are the people that should correct poorly fitting clues like this.

@Wggwg

As I‚Äôve said elsewhere I sympathize with everyone who pointed out the inaccuracies of the clue. But the NYT editorial staff doesn‚Äôt have an advisory board of geneticists, dermatologists, mechanical engineers, nuclear physicists, etc on staff or we‚Äôd be paying a heck of a lot more than about 17 cents a puzzle. For the price I feel like I‚Äôm getting an incredible deal.

@Wggwg but it isn't at all inaccurate! Clones share their entire genomes, and gene sets are subsets of genomes, so they are also the same.

The clue doesn't say that's ALL clones share. Even if the clue had said "basepair" it would have been accurate. I think it's a good example of a clever twist in cluing, which should happen on Thursdays.
@Mike I had these two niggles too but otherwise I thought this a superlative puzzle. Not complaining if this is the standard.

@Leontion

Well it‚Äôs not strictly inaccurate but it is a little green painty. It would be like if the answer were EYECOLOR. Sure clones share eye color but they share tons of other things as well. I feel pretty sure that the clue writer didn‚Äôt really understand the technical meaning of GENESETS but really meant it be ‚Äúa set of (all) genes‚Äù. Which is still fine by me, and worth discussing the intricacies of it, but not worth acting like the editors should have known better or didn‚Äôt do their jobs, IMHO.
@SP I disagree that this is too technical to understand without being an expert. Like you just have to read the definition of the term to realise it‚Äôs off
@Leontion would you think bone set is an equally good answer? Because all the reasons gene set are bad applies equally to bone set, but both are technically equally valid

@Fact Boy
That's a maxi answer for a mini puzzle  :)
@Fact Boy Whoop, whoop--a math guy.

@Fact Boy
zounds.

Fact Boy,

And my journey of ten thousand paces always gets put off by great rabbit holes like this :)

@SP

Had the crossers been harder, it would have resulted in Saturday difficulty, for me. This puzzle was challenging for me, pretty much at the high end of what I still consider a Friday rather than Saturday. I enjoyed, anyway.

@Mike
That pun was right on the hunny.
@SP it buzzed right over my head üêù

@Mike

If that's Eeyore story, I'd stick to it.

That one made me pause for a second but then I figured you could interpret it differently‚Äîthose who buy the season tickets are making sure they won‚Äôt (‚Äúcan‚Äôt?‚Äù) miss anything because of individual events selling out. Man, after yesterday's puzzle, speaking Yodic I can't stop!

@john ezra

Thank you john I wish everyone on this forum were so flexible.
@Derek I'm peds and I was trying to make it a rebus to get dermis in, but fortunately gave up

@Derek
Yep, also MD, have never heard of derma as a standalone word. Did a lit search and only recent paper I could see using the term had exclusively Italian authors, and it appears to be the translation of dermis in Italian

@Derek

So I‚Äôm a pediatrician and completely agree, it would have been much cleaner to clue it as a kishke holder. But here‚Äôs what happened, the constructor needed it to complete the puzzle, and then looked it up and the first thing that pops up is ‚Äúanother word for dermis‚Äù. Then they look up dermis and find out it‚Äôs the layer of skin that holds the hair follicles. He‚Äôs not a doctor, presumably, and neither are the editors, so how are they supposed to know it‚Äôs not in common use? So for educational purposes I certainly support pointing it out, but I‚Äôd be inclined to cut them some slack otherwise.
@Derek ENT here, same reaction as you. GENE SET was also a science swing-and-a-miss. Kludgy puzzle today!
@SP google it I guess? seems fairly trivial. This is a paid product. Probably better ways to clue derma anyway
@Derek To me, it‚Äôs a dish called stuffed derma, and let me tell you, that was really confusing

@Wggwg

Well when I googled it that‚Äôs what I got, so I figured a lay person wouldn‚Äôt be able to tell what was common usage and what wasn‚Äôt just by googling. But looks like Deb was confused as well so I‚Äôll let her be the final arbiter!
@SP I mean you could try ngram at least. I dunno, I expect some reasonable degree of editorial ability, rather than just using obsolete words and calling it good.

@Wggwg

All this sniping at James' puzzle is bringing out my MATERNAL instinct. Please stop POKING THE hAIR.

@Derek

@ŒôŒ±œÉœâŒΩ That was exactly my thought actually! 

Also strong agree about gene set. Ugh.

@ŒôŒ±œÉœâŒΩ and @John

Except that it didn‚Äôt, did it? ‚ÄòDerma‚Äô in Greek is ‚Äòskin,‚Äô not the particular [Skin layer with hair follicles], which is ‚Äòdermis‚Äô in English (and whose plural isn‚Äôt ‚Äòderma‚Äô).

@SP
I have the greatest respect for the constructors and editors. I could never do what they do. My humble suggestion is that they could have replaced ‚Äúderma‚Äù with ‚ÄúDARPA‚Äù. It would have been an easy fix to avoid an awkward clue.

@SP

I've actually heard of DARPA - I encountered it when I was researching the history of the internet as part of my academic career.

@Deb Amlen

You beat me to it! Every NY-ish Jew of a certain age has eaten stuffed derma at weddings or bar mitzvahs in the 50s-70s. It was unheard of to put on a fancy reception and not serve that as a garnish with the prime rib dinner. Orange in color and a little spicy. It's really not a very exotic dish, since it's just a simple starchy filling stuffed into a casing. You eat sausages, don't you, Wordplayers??? And this isn't even meat, well, except for the schmaltz that gave it the distinctive taste.

@B

I loved it and miss it!
@Derek That clue was so bad I almost convinced myself there had to be a rebus for the IS in DERMIS.

@Wggwg
Maybe it should have been clued as a prefix or suffix, as in dermatitis or scleroderma. Or more accurately, a start or an end, as titis and sclero aren't words.

@Dave K.

Boy the nit-pickers are out in force tonight. There‚Äôs a question mark, which means it‚Äôs a little stretchy or a play on words. If I‚Äôm a person who feels like they ‚Äúcan‚Äôt miss‚Äù a game, I‚Äôll buy season tickets. Of course I could miss a game or buy them for another purpose, so that‚Äôs why there‚Äôs a question mark. I would even have let you slide if you just wanted to point it out for some reason; but to say it ‚Äúdoesn‚Äôt make sense whatsoever for the clue‚Äù is just being argumentative and really stretches the boundaries of common sense.

@SP The clue "stretches the boundaries of common sense", not my objection to it.

But thanks for letting me slide, that's incredibly important to me.

@Dave K.

No, actually, in my humble opinion, I think your objection to it and the way you stated it stretches the boundaries of common sense. But you are welcome to disagree. And I didn‚Äôt let you slide.

@Bill in Yokohama

That‚Äôs an interesting idea, I‚Äôve never bought season tickets so I never thought of it that way. Although if you are a season ticket holder in Green Bay not only do you never miss renewing them, you put them in your will and your kids fight over them.
@Bill in Yokohama What does AFAIK mean?

@Ms. Billie M. Spaight

Pardon my interruption, but AFAIK means "as far as I know".

@Dave K. 

I would consider "can't miss" a fair way to say "don't want to miss" expressively, similar to "must see TV" (which is, to be fair, nearly out of use too).

But, I thought the clue's "?" was pointing towards something more literal: that a set of season tickets has no games missing.

I'm tempted to tease people for missing the literal interpretation... but the story about season tickets being inherited reminded me of how they feel vaguely alien to me, like of a different culture. A reminder that common-seeming experiences aren't so universal as we think. I think I've never seriously entertained the idea of SEASON TICKETS, and likely know all I do of them from SITCOM plots. (They're far too LIKE for me. ...wait, no.)

I suppose it's no surprise that people can have every different experiences and associations, so much so that people struggle to interpret the clue the same way as the cluer. So perhaps it's best to consider it a missed connection; hope it goes better next time.

(...DERMA, on the other hand...)

@SP haha I‚Äôm not sure why Dave K‚Äôs comment seems to have got you so riled up. I wouldn‚Äôt say it doesn‚Äôt make ‚Äúany sense‚Äù, but it‚Äôs a bad clue.

A question mark at the end of a clue is an indicator of a play on words. A good version of such a clue makes you think of one thing, and then you realize how it can also work a different way.  When you have to make too many contortions for it to only kind of work, it‚Äôs a bad clue. This was not a good clue.

@Jeb Jones

It was the ‚Äúdoesn‚Äôt make any sense WHATSOEVER‚Äù. It clearly does make some sense in the way that I explained (and plenty of others agree). I came off condescending, which I regret, I don‚Äôt usually bother to say anything if people just say it was a confusing clue, or here‚Äôs another way to look at it, or for your information, or something like that‚Äîbut the way they wrote it made it sound like the constructor and the editors are complete idiots (and by extension, the solvers who did like it, which includes myself). So I went into defense mode. I stand by what I said but perhaps could have been a bit more polite about it. My sincere apologies, Dave.

@Jeb Jones

My first response got emu‚Äôd so I will try again. What riled me up was ‚Äúdoesn‚Äôt make ANY sense WHATSOEVER‚Äù. It clearly did make sense to me and lots of others and I explained why. I usually wouldn‚Äôt make a deal if someone says I didn‚Äôt like the clue, it was clunky, or here‚Äôs a nit about it, etc. But the way he worded it sounded like ‚Äúthe editors and constructor are completely stupid for using it‚Äù (and by extension the solvers who liked it, including myself). So I went into defensive mode and admittedly was a bit condescending, which I regret. I don‚Äôt retract what I said but I could have been more polite and less snarky about it. You have my sincere apologies for that, Dave.

commentBody:
@Shaleen
STEM the tide of something.

A common phrase is "to stem the tide" meaning to attempt to push back or stop something forceful or possibly unstoppable. You can also stem the flow of blood by applying bandages.

I thought it was refreshing and perfectly accurate.
@Andrzej. I used to do the puzzles with a sharpie, but then I got tired of cleaning my phone.

I often think that I'd be wise to start from the bottom on those days (like today), and then I remind myself that I don't really care about time.

Enjoy the ride!

@The X-Phile

I was solving after a mostly sleepless night and before I had coffee. For reasons known only to the gods of insomnia, I was so set on an American location, that I had to get Alberta almost entirely from crosses. ‚ÄúNot Alabama, surely,‚Äù thought I, ‚ÄúBut let‚Äôs see, what counties and cities start with Al- ?‚Äù

And for all I knew about the movie, it might have been Canadian. 

Gah.

@Sam Lyons

Well, if it were a Polish mobie I would have fixated on a Polish location, too, even after a peaceful night's sleep. If the answer were Czech, I'd be stumped.

@Andrzej

I grew up in northwest Montana, and worked in Wyoming for several years.  I was hoping the answer would be either one of them.  C'mon, the Tetons or Glacier Nationl Park would have been perfect.

@Andrzej

Exactly, hence Altoona before Alberta for me (albeit very, very briefly‚Ä¶)
@Lars as does ALBaniA.
And Atlanta, which has been making a big push for film companies lately, though I didn't think it went that far back.  (I had the first and last A at that point.)

The Brokeback Mountain story as written was for a Wyoming location. Movie production frequently uses other locations due to concerns such as weather, amenities, politics, prejudices, cost, enticements, scenery, etc. Back in the day John Wayne showed up in my town for the filming of Hellfighters. The reason given was that the location was considered a look-alike for somewhere in Venezuela. I just missed bumping into John Wayne at our local Drug/Liquor/Gun Store. You know, the one with the drive-up window. He had been there to look at guns.

Exactly, and as pointed out elsewhere, its plural is not derma. Derma is not a plural of anything‚Äîin English, Latin, or Greek.

Dabbling with SFX makeup in my teens for ambitious fancy dress costumes lead me to a product called DERMA Wax which was the only way I had any real confidence in using it as an answer. I started questioning whether it was a Rebus day for a moment there mind you.

I have to imagine if a person who is an expert in every field attempted to do these crosswords, they would be one miserable soul.  Luckily I am not that, so I can merrily fill in the answer the puzzle wants, get my gold star, and not find out until the comments that it is wrong.

@Geoff Offermann

Ooh, that would be nice. The video game Civilization had that feature in the early 90s. It was awesome.

@Geoff Offermann

That would be a blast. Occasionally Deb used to do this‚Äîshow grids of how she got a foothold into the puzzle, and gradually added more fill, at least for the early parts. Haven‚Äôt seen any of the columnists do this lately. And yes Andrzej that was a fun feature of Civilization and I miss it. It would be nice to review how we conquered the crossword!

@Geoff Offermann
Actually that is precisely how some versions of AI work: they track what you do.
So an AI- enabled xword app could be coming soon.
Beware what you wish for.

@Geoff Offermann

There are of course various screen recorders that could do this...

Snipping Tool is a mostly-built-in one on Win11.

Android has Screen Record built in (swipe down to find it.)

@Suzanne
I loved that I popped it in there right away, thinking, well this fits, but it's going to be wrong, but....

@Rich in Atlanta
I remember that one!!!  And the dreaded name of Henry Hook!
@Doug Schoemer I thought it was meant to be a single word and kept wondering how ATTACKED was likely to smear.
@Doug Schoemer ATTACKAD was my last fill, and I did literally execute a face-palm upon enlightenment. :)

@Steve L Dig your feet in the ground all you want, the fact of the matter is it's not used in a way that's intuitive to solving the puzzle. I don't think if the editors put a note about the term being dated in the clue it would've made it that much easier. When professionals in the field are telling you that it's not correct, maybe it's time to put the dictionary and the "um, actually" responses away for a bit.

@Steve L I agree with you. If it‚Äôs in the dictionary, it‚Äôs fair game. Late week puzzles are supposed to be challenging and stretch your brain a little. I always expect answers to be ‚Äúiffy‚Äù on Friday and Saturday ü§∑üèº‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è I plugged in DERMA without a thought

userLocation: Hogtown, a great place for beer
commentBody:
@D
Experts are experts, bless 'em, and I've picked my share of nits. But that's not necessarily or even remotely reflective of 'the language how she is spoke.' I'm interested in an expert's opinion about specialized usage but that doesn't erase the plain meaning in ordinary English of a phrase like GENESET. It means a bunch of genes grouped according to some principle. Let's move on.
@SBK I was referring to Steve's nit about DERMA but ok

@D

I will say this as plainly and clearly as I can. 

According to the rules of engagement, if a word exists, it‚Äôs fair game. It doesn‚Äôt have to be the best way to say something, it doesn‚Äôt have to be the most up to date way to say something. Most significantly, it doesn‚Äôt have to be how the people who work in the field it comes from use or don‚Äôt use it. Up to this point, I‚Äôm talking about the basic rules of crossword construction as they have existed since crosswords first showed up a hundred and some years ago. 

Anything else is opinion. You may not like certain words. It has been documented, for example, that many people have an aversion to the word ‚Äúmoist.‚Äù  That doesn‚Äôt make it a bad word. 

Other people don‚Äôt like words that they aren‚Äôt familiar with, or that are not used in their correct technical sense. (All those who nitpick at math cluing, form a line segment to the right.)

You and everyone else are entitled to have an opinion. But keep in mind, on Fridays and Saturdays, clues are meant to not be intuitive or easy.  Too many people want to be able to solve every puzzle with no challenge. Would [Stuffed ___] been a better clue for you? If you‚Äôve heard of the dish, maybe. If not, you‚Äôd probably cry ‚ÄúToo obscure!‚Äù

A line has to be drawn via-√†-vis usability, and that line is often simply ‚ÄúIs it a word?‚Äù 
Not ‚ÄúIs it everyone‚Äôs favorite word?‚Äù And DERMA is a word. 

Disagree if you must. I‚Äôve been doing these for a long time.

@Steve L

That's a fine lecture but I believe it isn't necessary since only one person said the word didn't exist, and the rest of the comments were valid dislikes.

@Mr Dave

If you had carefully read my last post, you'd have noticed that I wasn't addressing the "it's not a word" crowd (of one, according to your count), but rather the "yeah, it's a word, but it's a lousy word, and should have been edited out because no one uses it" crowd.

@Steve L

The word is obsolete. It‚Äôs simply not used to mean dermis in modern English‚Ä¶ just look the ngram examples you‚Äôre attempting to use to justify it. It‚Äôs not even found in several dictionaries any more. If they had to use and clue the word in this way, then using a ‚Äúonce‚Äù, or ‚Äúvar‚Äù to indicate it‚Äôs no longer a term in English is necessary.

@SBK if you‚Äôre using ‚Äúgene set‚Äù to just mean set of genes separate to its technical definition, it‚Äôs a pretty weak answer. As I said above, would you also accept ‚Äúbone set‚Äù as a valid answer to that clue?

@Steve L

The ngram instances are all brand names. It is simply not a word that means dermis. There are 19th c. examples in medical literature from the halcyon days of early New Latin when terms were being coined left and right, but then those rowdy kids grew up. 

It‚Äôs in (some) dictionaries so that if someone finds ‚Äòderma‚Äô in an old text, they can look it up. That doesn‚Äôt make it a word that‚Äôs been used in the last 100 years. 

There are instances when the editors are just plain wrong. This is one of those times.
@Anonymous I guess another acceptable answer would be ‚Äúbone set‚Äù, as they share all the same bones?

@Wggwg

Obviously that doesn‚Äôt work‚Ä¶and I‚Äôm confident you understand why.
@Anonymous it works in the exact same way that gene set works

@Mean Old Lady
I got it after genome, but was also perplexed by gene set.
@Jeb Jones To each their own! Glad you liked :)
@The X-Phile I was very thrown off my that - there's van der Eyck, but had not heard of van der Meer? Apparently Vermeer is a contraction of van der Meer, but not much to be found on the internet.

@Nancy after purchasing school supplies for the last 26 years straight, I can assure you that erasers are on every school supply list that I‚Äôve seen and that includes California, Arizona, Texas and Wisconsin! The pencils long live out their attached erasers, ergo the supplemental eraser request. Whiteboard erasers are also sometimes requested.

@Nancy
Wow, you've never owned a Pink Pearl? Drafting/drawing pencils don't come with an attached ERASER, so a separate one is essential. Mine is an art gum.

commentBody:
@Vaer

Back when I used a pencil a lot, I'd sometimes absent-mindedly scratch the inside of my ear with the eraser.

All it takes is one time, and it ruins the eraser.  It gets weirdly hard and won't absorb graphite any longer.

It becomes and ex-eraser.

Cat Lady Margaret,

[Answer to ‚ÄúElliott, why don‚Äôt human finger-tips glow?‚Äù]

userLocation: Hogtown, a great place for beer

commentBody: @Jim  This is one of my frustrations with Times blogs in general. Their  AI seems to pick up any word that sounds at all offensive or "uncivil" (even if it's used in the article I'm commenting on) and either block the comment for hours or zap it at the start. For the crossword blog, we should at least be grateful it doesn't max out after a few hundred comments.

@SBK

What I am highlighting here is the automated filter that does not involve humans.  Certain words cause a comment to get delayed automatically.  When humans can get to these delayed comments, they determine whether or not they should be published.  That was the case here.  All comments containing the potential culprit words were delayed, but then later released upon review by a human.

@Jim

Actually "delayed automatically" is not correct.   I should have said "blocked automatically".  Some comments are only delayed, but others may never get published.
@Heather K It took me forever to get that airport clue, and I've flown in and out of it! (It was a loooong time ago.)

@Jeanne when I first moved away from NYC, someone asked where I was from, and I said "the Village".
The village? What village?
Greenwich Village. It's in the City.
The city?? What city??

@Amy
When I moved to my current location, I learned that ‚ÄúThe City‚Äù has a different meaning west of the Rockies.
@Jeanne I had just enough letters for Austria.  Beautiful scenery, mountains, etc. But knew it just couldn't be.

@Amy
Waiting for the UK contingent to chime in that The City is London, full stop. (Technically, the financial district.)

commentBody:

P.S. Do you have cedar shakes on the roof of your outdoor lav?

P.P.S. I dimly recall "lavatory" as the sign on one-holers on (pre-Amtrak) railroad passenger cars.

@Barry Ancona - My putdoor LAV consists of an old urinal I mounted on the railing of my deck overlooking the lake. 

It is open air and has no walls or roof, so no cedar SHAKEs. 

My memory of my elementary and middle school bathrooms was that they were labeled BOYS LAVATORY and GIRLS LAVATORY and we shortened that to LAV in everyday parlance. 

You had to have a LAV pass to go during class times.
